annotation.spannedText: Pediatric vaccine programs in the United States have been extremely successful against a range of contagious diseases, including measles, rubella, tetanus, diphtheria, and poliomyelitis

classMention.mentionClass: Pediatric vaccine programs in the United States have been extremely successful against a range of contagious diseases, including measles, rubella, tetanus, diphtheria, and poliomyelitis

annotation.spannedText: healthy adults also require regular vaccines

classMention.mentionClass: healthy adults also require regular vaccines

annotation.spannedText: Receiving appropriate immunizations plays a crucial role in protecting health throughout a person’s lifetime

classMention.mentionClass: Receiving appropriate immunizations plays a crucial role in protecting health throughout a person’s lifetime

annotation.spannedText: Vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies

annotation.spannedText: unlike bacteria and viruses, vaccines do not cause the person to become ill in order to develop these antibodies

classMention.mentionClass: unlike bacteria and viruses, vaccines do not cause the person to become ill in order to develop these antibodies

annotation.spannedText: vaccines have a long record of being a safe and effective way of preventing disease

classMention.mentionClass: vaccines have a long record of being a safe and effective way of preventing disease

annotation.spannedText: In most cases, the benefits of vaccinating are much greater than the potential risks

classMention.mentionClass: In most cases, the benefits of vaccinating are much greater than the potential risks

annotation.spannedText: Vaccines help to reduce a child's, family's, and even an entire community's chances of becoming ill by decreasing the number of people who become sick and transmit the infection to other people

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccines help to reduce a child's, family's, and even an entire community's chances of becoming ill by decreasing the number of people who become sick and transmit the infection to other people

annotation.spannedText: An example of a successful vaccine program is smallpox

classMention.mentionClass: An example of a successful vaccine program is smallpox

annotation.spannedText: Before a vaccine was available, smallpox killed millions of people every year

classMention.mentionClass: Before a vaccine was available, smallpox killed millions of people every year

annotation.spannedText: As a result of an intensive vaccination program, smallpox has been completely eliminated throughout the world

classMention.mentionClass: As a result of an intensive vaccination program, smallpox has been completely eliminated throughout the world

annotation.spannedText: Most vaccines are safe and cause few if any serious side effects

classMention.mentionClass: Most vaccines are safe and cause few if any serious side effects

annotation.spannedText: Very rarely, serious side effects do occur

classMention.mentionClass: Very rarely, serious side effects do occur

annotation.spannedText: People who are vaccinated and then develop symptoms that could be related to the vaccine should contact their healthcare provider

classMention.mentionClass: People who are vaccinated and then develop symptoms that could be related to the vaccine should contact their healthcare provider

annotation.spannedText: If a severe reaction occurs later, the person or a family member should call emergency medical services, available in most areas of the United States by calling 911

classMention.mentionClass: If a severe reaction occurs later, the person or a family member should call emergency medical services, available in most areas of the United States by calling 911

annotation.spannedText: A mild allergy to eggs does not mean that the vaccine should be avoided

classMention.mentionClass: A mild allergy to eggs does not mean that the vaccine should be avoided

annotation.spannedText: In this case, the vaccination should be delayed for one month

classMention.mentionClass: In this case, the vaccination should be delayed for one month

annotation.spannedText: Ideally, children should begin receiving vaccinations at birth

classMention.mentionClass: Ideally, children should begin receiving vaccinations at birth

annotation.spannedText: Adults aged 65 years or older who are healthcare workers or who have close contact with infants under one year of age (eg, grandparents, childcare providers) should get a single dose of Tdap as soon as they can, regardless of how long ago they had a tetanus booster

classMention.mentionClass: Adults aged 65 years or older who are healthcare workers or who have close contact with infants under one year of age (eg, grandparents, childcare providers) should get a single dose of Tdap as soon as they can, regardless of how long ago they had a tetanus booster

annotation.spannedText: Vaccination can help to eliminate the most important consequences of rubella, including miscarriage, fetal death, and congenital rubella syndrome

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccination can help to eliminate the most important consequences of rubella, including miscarriage, fetal death, and congenital rubella syndrome

annotation.spannedText: Healthcare workers born before 1957 whose blood test does not show measles or mumps immunity or who do not have laboratory confirmation of having had disease, vaccination with two doses of MMR should be considered

classMention.mentionClass: Healthcare workers born before 1957 whose blood test does not show measles or mumps immunity or who do not have laboratory confirmation of having had disease, vaccination with two doses of MMR should be considered

annotation.spannedText: During outbreaks of measles or mumps, such individuals should receive two doses of MMR

classMention.mentionClass: During outbreaks of measles or mumps, such individuals should receive two doses of MMR

annotation.spannedText: If you are in one of these high-risk groups and are not immune to measles, mumps, or rubella, you should receive two doses of the MMR vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: If you are in one of these high-risk groups and are not immune to measles, mumps, or rubella, you should receive two doses of the MMR vaccine

annotation.spannedText: If you are not in one of these high-risk groups and are not immune to measles, mumps, or rubella, you should receive one dose of MMR

classMention.mentionClass: If you are not in one of these high-risk groups and are not immune to measles, mumps, or rubella, you should receive one dose of MMR

annotation.spannedText: However, MMR should not be administered to pregnant women or women considering pregnancy in the next 28 days

classMention.mentionClass: However, MMR should not be administered to pregnant women or women considering pregnancy in the next 28 days

annotation.spannedText: It should not be used by people with a weakened immune system, pregnant women, or those with a history of a severe allergic reaction to gelatin or neomycin

classMention.mentionClass: It should not be used by people with a weakened immune system, pregnant women, or those with a history of a severe allergic reaction to gelatin or neomycin

annotation.spannedText: In addition, any adult who is at risk for HBV infection should receive the HBV vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: In addition, any adult who is at risk for HBV infection should receive the HBV vaccine

annotation.spannedText: Adults who should receive the HBV vaccine include: ●Healthcare and public safety workers ●Personnel in institutions caring for the developmentally disabled and employees and inmates of correctional facilities ●Household contacts and sex partners of people with chronic HBV ●Individuals with multiple sex partners, people with sexually transmitted diseases, and men who have sex with men ●People who inject street drugs ●People who require blood clotting factors or kidney dialysis ●People from countries where HBV is consistently present (endemic) and certain international travelers (see "Patient education: Vaccines for travel (The Basics)") ●People with diabetes who are between ages 19 and 59

classMention.mentionClass: Adults who should receive the HBV vaccine include: ●Healthcare and public safety workers ●Personnel in institutions caring for the developmentally disabled and employees and inmates of correctional facilities ●Household contacts and sex partners of people with chronic HBV ●Individuals with multiple sex partners, people with sexually transmitted diseases, and men who have sex with men ●People who inject street drugs ●People who require blood clotting factors or kidney dialysis ●People from countries where HBV is consistently present (endemic) and certain international travelers (see "Patient education: Vaccines for travel (The Basics)") ●People with diabetes who are between ages 19 and 59

annotation.spannedText: People with anaphylactic reactions to yeast should not receive HBV vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: People with anaphylactic reactions to yeast should not receive HBV vaccine

annotation.spannedText: Vaccinating children can help to protect adult caregivers from a potentially serious illness

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccinating children can help to protect adult caregivers from a potentially serious illness

annotation.spannedText: Washing the hands can help to prevent infection

classMention.mentionClass: Washing the hands can help to prevent infection

annotation.spannedText: Vaccines are available to prevent infection with HAV

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccines are available to prevent infection with HAV

annotation.spannedText: Both are equally effective in preventing infection

classMention.mentionClass: Both are equally effective in preventing infection

annotation.spannedText: People who were previously vaccinated against hepatitis A should contact their healthcare provider to determine which vaccine was given and if revaccination is needed

classMention.mentionClass: People who were previously vaccinated against hepatitis A should contact their healthcare provider to determine which vaccine was given and if revaccination is needed

annotation.spannedText: Women who are pregnant should discuss the risks and benefits of the HepA vaccine with their obstetrical healthcare provider

classMention.mentionClass: Women who are pregnant should discuss the risks and benefits of the HepA vaccine with their obstetrical healthcare provider

annotation.spannedText: Your healthcare provider is the best source of information for questions and concerns related to your medical problem

classMention.mentionClass: Your healthcare provider is the best source of information for questions and concerns related to your medical problem
